## A. Is This What the Drafters Had in Mind? Re-evaluating the U.N. Charter Through a Digital Lens
The most significant anticipated criticism is that the U.N. Charter was only intended to prevent physical uses of force and harm. Characterizing Articles 2(4) and 51 as mere limits on the use of kinetic armed force used between states tells only part of the story. Although the text of the Charter and context of its creation do not provide a clear definition of "use of force" and "armed attack," scholars can derive the intended scope of these Articles by looking at customary international law and subsequent state practice. Through a careful evaluation of the development and scope of the Charter, this Paper argues that the Articles are primarily concerned with protecting states from imminent, potentially irreversible threats to their territorial integrity and political independence, and are not limited to physical attacks. Therefore, this Paper is consistent with the original principles of the U.N. Charter.

## B. Fear of Escalation
A second anticipated criticism, which is often heard regarding the scope of Article 51, is the fear of escalation.¹⁵⁵ The argument is that by broadening the scope of what a state may respond to with force, states will employ force in situations that the target state may deem to be an illegal use of force, leading to a cycle of increasingly severe uses of force. In practice, however, this framework only acknowledges as legal responses that states would already undertake, bringing international law into harmony with state practice.
This “slippery slope” argument is important to take into account, but the framework proposed in this Paper does not contribute to an escalation of violence. First, it is important to note that even where Article 51 is triggered, there remains a strict application of the principles of necessity and proportionality.¹⁵⁶ Target states seeking to exercise their Article 51 rights would need to first exhaust all viable legal options, and show that their use of force would be a last resort. In the eighteenth century, states believed that the only legal requirement for going to war was to make a manifesto/declaration of war.¹⁹ In the absence of an international governmental framework, the only way to resolve disputes was through war. ## i. The"Instrument-Based"Approach One approach to analyzing the force of cyber attacks is to look at the method of delivery.³³ This is commonly referred to as the"instrument-based"approach. This framework would categorize cyber-attacks by the method through which an attack occurs. Some scholars argue that an attack can be an armed attack only if it uses conventional weapons, precluding a cyber attack's ever triggering self-defense.³⁴ The approach would differentiate attacks carried out by viruses, worms, network intrusions, Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS), etc. The instrument-based approach would categorize attacks utilizing certain types of"weapons"as armed attacks. ### iii. The “Effects-Based” Approach The third approach that has been put forward is the “effects-based” approach. This is currently accepted as the best of the possible approaches, and is relied on heavily by the Tallinn Manual.⁴⁷ As such, it is worth examining the proposed framework and the variants that scholars have put forth. ## iv. Alternative Approaches Several other scholars have put forth alternative frameworks to analyze when self-defense is authorized based on a cyber attack. These approaches range from looking at the “cyber-physical” characteristics of a target, relying on the U.N. Security Council for responses to cyber-attacks, and responding to such attacks with countermeasures. Each of these approaches is either overbroad, too narrow, or impractical. Therefore, none of these satisfactorily answers the problems that cyber-attacks create in international law.
For instance, Reese Nguyen advocates a framework that is “administrable across nation-states, forward-looking, and both consistent and sensible in its treatment of cyber attacks.”72 Nguyen proposes that cyber-attacks be considered This content downloaded from 144.82.114.237 on Wed, 23 Apr 2025 12:43:30 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms Journal of Law and Cyber Warfare [2014] armed attacks where “they are intended to cause irreversible disruption or physical damage to a cyber-physical system.”73 A cyber-physical system is a computer system controlling a physical process. Nguyen’s analysis is based on the premise that “cyber attacks that do not threaten or result in physical effects should not constitute force under the jus ad bellum, because such attacks are largely reversible.”74 Nguyen’s approach is one of the best attempts at developing an applicable framework for analyzing cyber-attacks, but suffers from several shortcomings. While her intention and purpose are certainly on-point, the approach advocated by Nguyen is both over- and under-inclusive. This framework covers all attacks that are “intended” to cause physical damage, meaning that an attack need not be successful to warrant self-defense. Under this approach, if a firewall detected and prevented a cyber-attack or virus that was nevertheless intended to cause damage, the target state would be allowed to respond in kind. Every day, countless such attacks are detected and prevented by governments and private companies, and this approach would allow for self-defense retaliation for each of those attacks.75 This would have the effect of This content downloaded from 144.82.114.237 on Wed, 23 Apr 2025 12:43:30 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms A Brave New World... Additionally, this approach is under-inclusive in that it requires a physical aspect for an attack to qualify as an armed attack. In the modern age, a crippling cyber attack that knocks out an entire country's access to the Internet and related networks could be more damaging than a physical attack. As such, any adequate framework should acknowledge that countries should have the ability to respond in the event that they are faced with such an event. Nguyen's framework does not acknowledge this, and as such is inadequate.

An increasingly popular focus has been to propose that states rely on countermeasures to respond to cyber-attacks that do not reach the level of an armed attack.79 In the international law context, countermeasures are “measures which would otherwise be contrary to the international obligations of the injured State vis-à-vis the responsible State if they were not taken by the former in response to an internationally wrongful act by the latter in order to procure cessation and reparation.”80 Schmitt reasons that many cyber-activities not amounting to an armed attack still amount to an “internationally wrongful act” justifying countermeasures.81 Placing malware on a system, hacking into a network, and destroying data all violate a state’s sovereignty, and abuse the principle of non-intervention. To Schmitt, countermeasures are an adequate way to respond to these attacks.
While an attractive alternative to Articles 2(4) and 51, countermeasures have several preconditions that make them quite limited and difficult to apply to cyber attacks. This fact would be emphasized by a cyber-attack that could cripple a State's network capabilities. A Growing Disconnect Between Scholarship and State Practice As has been demonstrated, there is something intuitively lacking about the current state This content downloaded from 144.82.114.237 on Wed, 23 Apr 2025 12:43:30 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms Journal of Law and Cyber Warfare [2014] of each of the leading frameworks, and none of the “alternate” solutions is sufficient to cover the problems that cyber-attacks present to *jus ad bellum*. Each one of these frameworks is either too over-inclusive, under-inclusive, or a mix of the two. While each of these frameworks has its specific problems, there is a more general problem that extends across the proposals. Inherent in each of the analyses is a fundamental disconnect between how countries would respond to cyber-attacks in the modern age and what the frameworks would allow. In other words, there is a general collective opinion of what constitutes tolerable cyber-conduct and what exceeds that threshold of tolerance and will trigger forceful responses. An acceptable framework of analysis would need to encapsulate and reflect that general consensus; however, none of the leading frameworks do so.
For instance, it seems intuitive that were the United States the victim of an all-out cyber attack shutting down all government and financial cyber operations, we would treat that as a hostile attack.⁹⁰ Whether or not we chose to retaliate with armed force, it seems likely that if we knew where the attacks were coming from, we would at the very least respond with offensive cyber capabilities. Although this approach does a better job by acknowledging that what formerly could be achieved only with physical force can now be achieved using cyber-attacks, it still falls short. It is generally accepted that for an attack to pass the effects-based test, there must be physical damage comparable to that caused by a conventional attack that would be considered to be an armed attack. This fails to acknowledge that in the digital age, countries can achieve hugely strategic gains purely through cyber conduct that has no physical consequences at all.
By failing to take into account the strategic importance and prevalence of cyber resources and infrastructure, these approaches set the threshold for what constitutes an armed attack too high. This creates a disconnect between what events trigger lawful self-defensive measures under international law (attacks causing physical damage), and what states will actually respond to (attacks that severely undermine strategic cyber resources). As they do not adequately acknowledge the growing significance of damage from cyber-attacks, these frameworks have foreseeable negative consequences. First, they undermine the international legal framework; second, they have the potential for severe escalation.

## C. The Advantages of this Framework Looking to this Paper's definition, it should be apparent that it combines the policy advantages of the target-based and effects-based approaches, while attempting to minimize their shortcomings. To review, the advantage of the target-based approach is that it acknowledges a state's unique interest in actively defending its most important resources and infrastructure. The criticism of that approach is that it covers all attacks on those resources, even where the attack had limited chances of causing substantial damage. In this way, the target-based approach was over-broad. On the other hand, the effects-based approach is conversely problematic. While that approach only covers those attacks demonstrating severe effects, it covers attacks on any target, including purely commercial targets unlikely to result in any strategic or sovereign implications. In this way, the effects-based approach was overbroad. As Schmitt describes, prior to the advent of cyber operations, there was a close congruence between the “normative shorthand” and the consequences the international community sought to limit.¹⁵¹ In other words, at the time of drafting, severe infringements on state sovereignty, territorial integrity, and political independence could only be achieved through military kinetic force. ## B. Fear of Escalation A second anticipated criticism, which is often heard regarding the scope of Article 51, is the fear of escalation.¹⁵⁵ The argument is that by broadening the scope of what a state may respond to with force, states will employ force in situations that the target state may deem to be an illegal use of force, leading to a cycle of increasingly severe uses of force. In practice, however, this framework only acknowledges as legal responses that states would already undertake, bringing international law into harmony with state practice.
This “slippery slope” argument is important to take into account, but the framework proposed in this Paper does not contribute to an escalation of violence. First, it is important to note that even where Article 51 is triggered, there remains a strict application of the principles of necessity and proportionality.¹⁵⁶ Target states seeking to exercise their Article 51 rights would need to first exhaust all viable legal options, and show that their use of force would be a last resort. ## IV. Conclusion In this case, it is worth taking a lesson from history. Prior to the twentieth century, under the “Grotian” view of international law, armed conflict was largely the norm.¹⁸⁵ A country merely had to declare war on another country for any variety of reasons (debt, personal offenses to leaders, etc.), and the war was presumptively legitimate. At the very least, no one in the international community was going to dispute the results of the war as being wrongful. This led to an increasing number of wars and loss of life, ultimately resulting in World War I. As long as no kinetic destruction occurs as a result of a cyber-attack, the international community seems to consider these attacks presumptively legitimate. To this point, no frameworks have been proposed that accurately reflect the developing international perceptions on what is a tolerable cyber-attack, and what would trigger Article 51 self-defense. By laying out definitions that are not dependent on a physical nexus, this Paper brings into the scope of Article 51 conduct that states would already engage in – responses to attacks significantly disrupting a state’s military, critical, or strategic infrastructure. By focusing on the aggressive intent an accumulation of attacks, this proposal remains consistent with the underlying policies of the U.N. Charter, while applying dated definitions to the digital age. In doing so, this Paper proposes a framework that countries can abide by and support, and that will encourage regulation of the increasingly common use of cyber-attacks.

metadata.title: A Brave New World: Applying International Law of War to Cyber-Attacks
metadata.abstract: State and non-state actors are using international cyber-attacks with an increasing frequency and magnitude, causing new levels of damage and disruption. Despite this growing significance, the legal status of cyber-attacks in international law remains unclear. Cyber-attacks do not fit under the conventional analyses of “use of force” and “armed attacks” under the UN Charter, and no satisfactory approaches have been put forth to treat cyber-attacks. This Paper puts forth a test for whether cyber-attacks constitute a “use of force” and “armed attack” that reflects the traditional goals of the UN Charter, while taking into account the present realities of the use of cyber-attacks.
